intro: Tragacantha andersonii, commonly known as the Anderson's tragacanth, is a rare flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Fabaceae family and is characterized by its small, showy flowers that bloom in spring. The plant produces a unique, sticky resin that has been historically used in traditional medicine. It thrives in arid environments and is often found in rocky soils. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
